Topic.Title: Sales of Windows in China and India

Message.Msg: Never had any issues with Ubuntu drivers. As for office, I use the free Microsoft Online Docs, and have used the free Google Docs - no problems. But then again, OpenOffice is usually OK... I can see where there could be issues for business however. I had a Win8 machine for two weeks, it wigged-out and was returned and I am using OS X now, on a Mac Mini. I do like Win7, but found Win8 quirky, but sometimes entertaining..... that is before it failed .... could be the brand of computer, which I won't get into, and I would just rate as a D.

Topic.Title: Microsoft’s Sales Weaker Than Expected

Message.Msg: From the same source. The bloody awful surface has sunk.... ================================ Is the Surface Running Scared of Apple’s iPad? By Aabha Rathee | More Articles December 25, 2012 Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPad was the most popular tablet at retail stores during last week’s intense shopping period, according to R.W. Baird’s William Power. By comparison, Microsoft’s Surface (NASDAQ:MSFT) did not make a very successful start. In addition, Amazon’s (NASDAQ:AMZN) Kindle Fire and Samsung’s Galaxy Tab line were “frequently cited alternatives,” while the Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) Nexus 10 was also a strong option. Our 20-page proprietary analysis of Apple’s stock is ready. Click here to get your Cheat Sheet report now. How Did all the Tablets Fare? “Microsoft’s Surface, which Best Buy just recently started carrying, was not recommended to us by reps without us asking about it specifically,” Power wrote in a note to researchers, according to Barron’s. “When asked about sales to date, reps noted that the device was new and indicated that early demand has been modest relative to the iPad and Kindle Fire.” Power added that retail executives indicated that Surface sale volumes had been modest, with the primary appeal for its Surface buyers being the tablet’s ability to run Microsoft Office. “Consistent with our Best Buy checks, the Surface was also in stock at all Staples stores we contacted,” the analyst said. ==============================

Topic.Title: Microsoft’s Sales Weaker Than Expected

Message.Msg: From the same source.....looks like the rubbish Surface has sunk...... ================================================= Is the Surface Running Scared of Apple’s iPad? By Aabha Rathee | More Articles December 25, 2012 Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPad was the most popular tablet at retail stores during last week’s intense shopping period, according to R.W. Baird’s William Power. By comparison, Microsoft’s Surface (NASDAQ:MSFT) did not make a very successful start. In addition, Amazon’s (NASDAQ:AMZN) Kindle Fire and Samsung’s Galaxy Tab line were “frequently cited alternatives,” while the Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) Nexus 10 was also a strong option. Our 20-page proprietary analysis of Apple’s stock is ready. Click here to get your Cheat Sheet report now. How Did all the Tablets Fare? “Microsoft’s Surface, which Best Buy just recently started carrying, was not recommended to us by reps without us asking about it specifically,” Power wrote in a note to researchers, according to Barron’s. “When asked about sales to date, reps noted that the device was new and indicated that early demand has been modest relative to the iPad and Kindle Fire.” Power added that retail executives indicated that Surface sale volumes had been modest, with the primary appeal for its Surface buyers being the tablet’s ability to run Microsoft Office. “Consistent with our Best Buy checks, the Surface was also in stock at all Staples stores we contacted,” the analyst said. ===================================================

Message.Title: Well if there was ethics in technoland Microsoft would start stretching its PE and AAPL would fall back to a realistic market cap
Message.Msg: How can MSFT do this. Stay consistent with the PC there is alot of bluffing from leaders about deleting the PC market. Stay progressive with the OSs and always stay ahead of Apple with price/performance. Keep Xbox 360 going strong as long as the market will bear it. Work on more practical solutions to cloud computing for the enterprise. And if all strength in all areas is maxed out develop another competitor in software that will run the mobile stuff. As long as folks need a toilet and a sink and a bed we will need our Microsoft PCs !!!

Message.Title: Surface and Windows 8-- the new revolution
Message.Msg: Who is this clown from NY times, Fromont? His estimates of Windows 8 is not selling as expected? I believe only the Financial officers of msft would know that. His estimates????!!!! How did he derive to that conclusion? Didn't msft itself stated last week, "ramping up production of surface" Did msft lie? Did my eyes deceive me when I saw crowds of people buying surface laptops? Did my eyes deceive me when I saw the crowds in msft stores were just as large as apple stores? Surface- dual laptop and touchpad for $600-800. Ipad- $600 for original size and $329 for mini. If I wanted for bang for my bucks, I would buy Surface because I can use it as a laptop and as a touchpad. It is plain and simple as that. I don't believe in "Frodo" character.

Topic.Title: Sales of Windows in China and India

Message.Msg: The chinese and indians are known for their bargain shopping. They will not spend $300-600 for touchpads alone, so they can play "cut the rope" and "angry bird". They will want computers and laptops that do it all, for competitive price. That's half of the world's population of shrewd bargain shoppers. Surface is the first version, this hybrids of touchpad and laptops will dominate the future market. This Fromont character from NY times is a short!

Topic.Title: Let's lookat lefty looney 'Logic', ............................The "CONSERVATIVES' are destroying the economy?

Message.Msg: Rich Paid More Revenue Under Bush Tax Cuts While progressives attack the Bush tax cuts and President Barack Obama wants to let them expire for families making over $250,000, figures released by the IRS show the wealthiest 1% actually paid more in taxes after the Bush tax cuts were passed, and the bottom half of taxpayers actually paid less in income taxes. According to IRS data, the “richest 1% paid $84 billion more in taxes in 2007 than they had in 2000,” a 23% increase. In addition, their “share of the overall income tax burden grew, climbing from 37% in 2000 to 40% in 2007.” All this occurred even though their rates went down. The IRS numbers also found the bottom half of taxpayers “paid $6 billion less in income taxes in 2007 than they had seven years earlier,” which is a 16% decrease, and “their share of the total income tax burden actually went from 3.9% to 2.9%.” Further, as Investors Business Daily noted, the Bush tax cuts also pushed millions of people off of the tax rolls entirely because Bush “doubled the per-child tax credit to $1,000 and lowered the bottom rate to 10%.”
